Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Political Determinants of Economic Exchange

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Abstract
Confidence in basic economic exchange is an important building block for economies. This confidence in economic exchange is often affected by state institutions that possess the authority to enforce contracts which ensure agreements are not broken. In much of the world, however, weak state institutions limit the confidence of citizens and businesses that contracts and deals will be enforced fairly. As a result, economic exchange is stifled and inefficiencies persist. Understanding how contracts and economic exchange are affected, particularly in contexts where only a subset of individuals enjoy privileged access to state institutions, is essential for development yet not well understood. This project will assess how varying levels political connectivity influences economic exchange. The findings from this study will provide valuable insight as to how different strategies can spur economic development in areas where the rule of law is not evenly distributed among citizens.

Technical Abstract
This project consists of a conjoint experiment among firm leaders, as well as an innovative field experiment to assess how varying degrees of connectedness influences economic exchange in weak states. Building off existing work on political networks, contracting, and economic exchange in a weak state, this conjoint experiment will help to identify the characteristics of potential business partners that matter most to firms in developing economies. The randomized control trial (RCT) will test how political connections affect change in realistic contexts, by randomly varying signals of connections between the two parties engaged in exchange, and observing how these signals serve to shape the contracts and deals that result. The findings will be among the first causal estimates of the impact of political connections on economic exchange.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to test the impact of political considerations on private economic exchange (i.e. how business is conducted) in developing countries. To do so, the project consisted of two parts: a field experiment to test individual participation in exchange, and a survey to test firm-level factors. The field experiment aimed to specifically test the impact of political connections and formal contracts on individuals’ decisions to enter into private economic exchange. I launched and operated a business in Senegal through which goods were sold door-to-door to households; during transactions, sellers randomized a signal of political connections and the availability of formal contracts. This allowed me to test the causal effect of political connections and formal contracts on exchange. The results show that even in basic forms of economic exchange, political connections can suppress trade among ordinary citizens, but that formal contracts can mitigate some of the distrust that political connections cause. It further shows that asymmetries in political connections between buyers and sellers can affect the rates at which individuals willingly do business. 

Additionally, I implemented a survey among approximately 2,400 businesses in the formal and informal sector in Senegal. The survey included an embedded conjoint experiment which aimed to test the motivations for firms to do business with other firms. The results from this part of the survey show that firms in general distrust businesses whose leaders have strong political affiliations, but that these types of business partners are valuable nonetheless. Social factors such as ethnicity and religion are also substantial considerations in the business calculus of firms, particularly for those in the informal sector. The results also show that formal contracts can greatly increase confidence in deals and might spur business where it otherwise would not occur.

This project clarifies the role of political factors in trade, and suggests that policies that aim to reduce the effects of asymmetric political dynamics, while simultaneously increasing the availability of formal contracts, should be pursued for more stable private economic exchange in developing economies. Confidence in economic exchange is essential for economic growth, and the results from this project suggest several policy avenues for increasing this trust.
